text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new no such thing record
home no no such thing such a thing no
such thing is the pseudonym of West
Coast electronic music producer Jason
Chung a sophomore LP that has been
pretty anticipated thanks to the work
that Jason put into his semi breakout
debut album drift which came out in 2009
now this guy does make electronic music
but he's a beat meister as well he's a
guy whose productions showcased quite a
bit of hip hop influence on many tracks
from drift the beats and the grooves are
there but there are no MCS on this LP
and it's not really a hard-hitting or
edgy album either the sounds on here
shoot for a much more atmospheric kind
of glassy feel especially with the
synthesizer work and there's a bit of a
glitchy quality to the rhythms and the
sense on some songs as well and there
are some weird kind of experimental
sounds on this thing too like the
overuse of compression on some of the
beats here which kind of ends up making
the kick drums kind of seem like a black
hole a sonic black hole that sort of
when they hit they suck up every sound
around them mm which is sort of a
technique I've heard applied by other
artists that have made glitch hop and
and wonky albums like old Flying Lotus
work or like baths other artists from
the brain feeder collective and even
some chill wave acts like Toro y Moi
with the LP causers of this and
surprisingly Toro y Moi actually makes a
vocal appearance on this new LP and
blonde redheads kazuma Tino actually
makes a vocal appearance too on the
second track here there is definitely
evidence of Jason sort of capitalizing
on the attention and success that he's
had with drift in bringing in these
guest artists and even though the
successive drift does translate into
some interesting collaborations on home
the success doesn't really seem to kind
of peter out into anything else on this
new LP for the
this part I guess Jason tries to make
home a success merely on the back of his
stylistic progression as an artist since
the release of drift and he does make a
pretty apparent change on this new LP
which is kind of a surprise considering
just how many people who are fans of hip
hop kind of gravitated toward his music
as glitch hoppin and wonky were kind of
burgeoning genres in 2009 III on this
new LP the hip hop influence is here in
a few moments but it's not really as
strong or as potent as it used to be
he's not really fussing around with the
distorted bass sounds or just sort of
the hip-hop style rhythms and poly
rhythms that you would layer on top of
each other on track after track and in a
way I guess this is a positive because
it does make no such thing a little more
difficult to quickly compare the Flying
Lotus which is sort of an issue that a
live artists suffer from in these glitch
hop and wonky genres what keeps this
album feeling like a project from Jason
Chung even though there is sort of a
stylistic change is that he is still
working with a lot of sort of and being
quaint and sort of shy sounds I actually
feel a lot of influence from a guy like
new trapeze in his productions
especially the more hip-hop influenced
ones but with a much more electronic
direction as opposed to kind of like a
jazz influence now this very calming
kind of quality to know such things
music is consistent throughout this new
LP whether he is kind of fooling around
and sort of glitchy and familiar
territory with the song snap or bringing
on guest vocalists or kind of toying a
little bit with the sounds and rhythms
of to step with a few songs on here most
notably the track tell but even so I
gotta say I think because of the hip-hop
influence just the the stranger and more
experimental colors drift is gonna come
out the favor for people who have kind
of listened up until this point
especially since it for a lot of people
was the first album from this project
that they heard I actually think the
lack of a hip-hop vibe on this new LP
sort of subtracts what little edge no
such thing had so far
in the projects short career because a
lot of songs on here without these
hip-hop beats
sort of pulsate along very apathetically
and end at very inconspicuous song
lengths and just continue with kind of
uninspired progressions for sure Jason
chung is making a very noticeable
embrace of his ambient influences on
this LP or at least that's what it kind
of feels like I'm tracks like distance
which has these tender kind of ringing
synth tones murky bass and these reverb
synth riffs and with like a little bit
of added sound it kind of feels like an
electronic ode to an abandoned subway
tunnel again it sort of has that quaint
quality that I think comes so easily
from this projects music but it's not
really anything I would replay the song
safe shuffles along really serenely it's
got a very kind of nocturnal robotic
lullaby kind of quality to the
synthesizers and with these vocal
samples kind of hanging in the
background very faintly it's a sweet
track but it doesn't really pull that
much from me emotionally and the song
glue is a little bit more interesting
for me rhythmically it's got that future
garage kind of feel to it that I said
that Jason kind of toys with a little
bit on this album along with the song
tell and it's sort of as if he wanted
his fans to hear this kind of shift in
his production style because these songs
are noticeably louder than many other
tracks here but there are spots on here
that do feel familiar for no such thing
but I just kind of feel like the sounds
weren't crafted to be all that
interesting which is surprised because a
lot of the sounds were pretty good on
drift the tracks snap which has a
hip-hop influence to it rhythmically is
actually pretty flat and bland when it
comes to the sounds of the rhythm the
beat is just really kind of colorless I
guess and I do not get the sloppily
placed high hats and claps on the song
try either that just does not do
anything for me and beyond that I'm not
really sure if I'm feeling the auto-tune
vocals of Toro y Moi either overall I'm
feeling kind of indifferent on this elf
sadly I still like drift and and I still
think that album stands as a pretty good
release in genre that at the time was
making a lot of noise and was an
extremely interesting and new and
vibrant thing but this new album
unfortunately is is pleasant for sure
but nowhere near memorable I'm feeling a
decent 5 on this LP but if you've given
it a listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why and what
should I review next
Anthony Fantana home forever
